comments.commentBody:
It's interesting that people exist who are hoping Pope Francis is going to start making drastic changes, e.g. making abortion permissible, allowing homosexuals to be married in a Catholic Church, etc. In the first place, the Pope himself could not allow abortion. It is against the tenets of the faith. "Thou must not kill" is taken seriously by the Catholic Church.

As for homosexuals, the church has never been against the celibate homosexual who tries to live a godly life. The same standard is expected of the single Catholic person. But marriage will always be between a man and a woman, as far as the church is concerned. It cannot be otherwise. The remedy for homosexuals is a civil ceremony.

Where, where, where were the parents of these children? The adults, who are charged with parenting these children (yes, children) should be accountable.

They are regularly abusing alcohol in your house? They regularly stay out all night? From all accounts these children were allowed to live not being responsible or accountable. The parents who let this happen are to blame as well.
A simple question:   did none of the tens involved have any sense of right and wrong?

Such a good observation.

Parents who respect one another and model it for their kids in the way they treat one another, and also expect a high level of respect and compassion and courtesy from their children for the family and for greater world around them, are the best role models (and preventative pill) of all.

This is a terribly sad story for the young woman; it is also a terribly sad story, however inexcusable, for the young men.

Imagine what these lives could have been.

As a therapist who has specialized in working with troubled teens, I would respond to "Steve"'s comment by noting that if these boys' become MORE angry now, it is likely not because of their upcoming sentence, but rather because of the environmental influences (home/parents/town culture) that has already shaped them. Their treatment of women was a reflection of what they had been taught--and NOT taught--and it is now up to them to profit from a confined period of reflection. I myself hate to see kids this age end up in jail or a juvenile facility, but I think they're lucky that the young lady in question did not end up dead (and raped) at some point during that evening...their lives are not over, but on a different path brought about by their own actions. In short, there is nothing we are more responsible for in this life than our actions.

There may be some relief in the punishment (as weak as it is) but the perps who got off are the coach and the entire Steubenville community. The place that hero worships high school (!) footballers must be a pretty desperate place with no life, no culture, little sense of self beyond drunken aggressiveness on the Friday night.

This soulless desperation is what facilitated these attacks. Note that the two kids showed no real remorse beyond lamenting what conviction will do to their football careers. They had no sense that they had abused a defenseless girl, no compassion whatsoever. And yet you can rest assured that they went to church every Sunday.

This lack of humanity, compassion, is what i find truly scary.
Sigh. "No pictures should have been taken." Sounds like a real sincere apology.

An important element of this rape was parading the victim form party to party as a trophy.  The adults who permitted these drunken teen parties in their homes - and the adults who knew about the rape - also bear a share of the responsibility for this crime.  A few prosecutions in this area would have be a of great deterrence.

How hard is it to understand?

The victim of this crime was responsible for getting drunk. The consequence for this poor judgement is called a hangover.

The victim is not responsible for the crime perpetrated on her by her rapists, the consequences of which will alter her life forever.

That she got drunk certainly made her vulnerable, but a person that sees another human being's vulnerability as a license to commit a sexual assault is a criminal.

It's very simple. RAPISTS are the people responsible for RAPE. The end.
Imagine,  where a America puts the wellbeing of others before that of sports. Someday, we can only hope...
Well, for starters she will probably never trust men completely...possibly may be unable to have any healthy, long-term relationships with men. She will probably never trust women again either.

25 years ago Jodie Foster's Oscar winning performance in the film "The Accused" depicted the horrid gang rape of Sarah Tobias. I suggest those who blame this poor Ohio girl watch that file and learn a bit. It helped me internalize two concepts: 1) Consent to having sex cannot be inferred, but rather needs to be explicit and literal; and 2) Blaming the victim is a common tactic of sex offenders. I feel sad that what appeared to me was common and indisputable knowledge continues to elude many fellow citizens and their misguided and spoiled offspring.
Mark....if instead of a comatose woman they had raped a 4-year-old boy would you say the kid has to share some responsibility because he was helpless? You don't rape. End of story.

A lot of people were frustrated at the time by Hussein's defiance of UN weapons inspectors, but it all seems certain now that he possessed nothing more lethal than “weapons of mass distraction” as Professor Krugman dubbed them, and George Bush used them to justify his own personal vendetta against him. The case for war was apparently built on some satellite photos of a truck and perhaps some empty barrels outside a small building somewhere in the Iraqi desert. And we are still there for the same reason we invaded: because it's in the personal business interests of Bush, Dick Cheney and any number of other highly corrupt political cronies and executives from the arms industry - nobody but a fool could believe it was remotely related to anything noble about promoting democracy or to our security interests.

Democracy could still be an unintended consequence someday in the very distant future in the Mideast, but Americans rightly doubt whether it was worth the costs. Meanwhile, Cheney, along with hoods from finance, insurance, Big Pharma, Big Oil and others continue waging virtual war on a second front, seeking to weaken and enslave the US middle class, but the nation is at long last wising up to them. Knowing that Paul Krugman's articles are adding 20,000 tweets per week shows that his Gospel is spreading, and there's a lot more than glimmering hope that the US is returning to its former values.

I agree with your sentiments. I too am alarmed and ashamed at the throughly unprofessional and hostile response to Ms. Brown's article. Unfortunately, this confirms the toxic atmosphere that exists in many hospitals. I've been a nurse for over 30 years and am proud of the working relationship I've developed with 99% of the physicians I have worked with. But I'm afraid if I had the spend even one day with some of the disagreeable people that have posted comments on this article, I would have to leave that workplace.

I despaired of the idea that we, as a nation, could learn a lesson when I saw this country tripping over itself in joy at the prospect of committing hundreds of thousands of young men and women to this fools' errand in Iraq, and this less than thirty years after the end of the Vietnam debacle. The leaders, of course, took no part in the Vietnam conflict; some professed to have had other priorities. They all had sufficient access to privilege to avoid having to stand in harm's way, as their lessers had to.

It is a signal failure of education in the USA that young people know hardly anything of even the recent past. Without historical knowledge, young Americans were sitting ducks for the propagandists in the White House and their minions in Congress and in the press.

I have no doubt that, in a few years time, cynical people who make a living making war will have no trouble taking advantage of the best intentioned young flag-wavers when they see the next opport...crisis.

And how many know that every time we had a balanced budget for more than 3 years it led to a depression and the every depression we ever had was preceded by such a period of balanced budget?

And how many people know that the one time we had a deficit that was a larger percent of GDP, we increased spending and had deficits for most of the next 27 years and doubled the dollar amount of the debt, BUT we had great prosperity--real median household income surged 74%, average GDP growth was 3.8%, and the debt as a percent of GDP plummeted to less than a third of what it had been?

Clearly these facts are not even known to a lot of the liberal commenters here who act as though balancing the budget is a worthy goal.

Len,

My point was not that balancing the budget is a worthy goal, particularly now with high unemployment and a country physically coming apart at the seams.

My point was that Republican extremists are able to mount simple-minded arguments based on lies -- one in particular, that the budget deficit is higher than it has ever been and is growing out of control -- that all but a handful of Americans do not know are lies.

And yet, Mr. Appledorf, you and so many people commenting on this site are well informed, and draw cogent, rational, humane inferences from that information. So I am not sure the problem is the 6 corporations, real though that is. The real paradox is that in the USA, Pravda and pravda coexist side by side, and the latter can be found with only moderate effort. This wound is largely self-inflicted. We have met the enemy, and he is us.

Six percent of the American public know that the federal budget deficit has been reduced by half since 2009. Six percent.

Four hundred Americans own more wealth than the poorest 150 million.

The Walton family own more wealth than 1/3 of the American population. One hundred million people.

Americans do not know these things, and their minds are full of lies and disinformation because 6 corporations control more than 90% of the media in the United States.

Remember Pravda? The state-run propaganda machine of the USSR?

In the USA we have Pox News; Rush Limbaugh, and hate radio at the margins; and the other media who perhaps do not tell the Americans lies in every case but that fail to inform them of important information it is their duty to provide.

I have been a long time, but measured, admirer of Koppel's reporting and success. No more. His reporting from Iraq was clearly compromised by the embedding process. Every reporter suffered, to some degree, a version of the "Stockholm Syndrome" of over identification with their "hostage takers", the units to which they were assigned. Koppel went way overboard in that direction, from what I saw of his reporting.

Koppel to my ears turned into a person who very much wanted to see himself as an equal of Henry Kissinger and the other big shots he covered down through the years. Maybe they invited him to their houses and asked him for his carefully considered advice and it went to his head, I don't know. In his final years at "Nightline", he seemed to be trying to make himself over into a foreign policy expert.

In any case, your criticism of Koppel is on the mark. I would add, however, that almost everyone who had been a reporter for a long time by the early part of this century had heard mountains of criticism of the news media being left wing and not supporting the country in times of war. Iraq gave many a chance to "switch sides" and praise the brave service of the young men and women who went there. The media is highly political as to popular views and general acceptance and that certainly came into play. We all were ill served in the process, maybe even the military itself.

http://terryreport.com,

I agree with your thought, and Koppel looked ridiculous, but he at least said this (from memory), as the tanks were rolling over the border:

"Take a good look at this. We are invading another country with tanks".

Note that Koppel has been rarely seen on television since, and the same is true of Dan Rather. Goebbels and Machiavelli would have been proud.

Remember how the Bush administration allowed reporters to be "imbedded?" I will never forget the image of Ted Koppel riding into war in a tank wearing a military helmet. It made me realize that if this important and previously objective reporter could be co-opted, then everybody/anybody could be co-opted.
I also remember with gratitude that Professor Krugman was one of a very few who saw clearly that the Bush administration had violated previously-sacred American traditions, and he was willing to say so. At a time when I thought that my beloved country had literally gone crazy, Professor Krugman was a voice of sanity, and it has become clear over time how correct he was.

My experience as a lab tech in several large hospitals, is that nurses are just as likely to act as bullies as Drs.  Often when the lab notifies nurses with problems with a patients' specimen, it is the technologists who are blamed for poor collection procedures, mislabeling, and numerous other problems.  A proper diagnosis can not be made from inaccurate test results, and most nurses seem to forget this fact.  It is time to stop treating nurses as God's gift to the medical industry.  There are many of us who work in the medical field just as hard as nurses, just as educated, and get far less respect, recognition and pay for our contributions to patient care.

I don't know what Howie uses, but my main trick is trying to think like John, observing and googling accordingly. This guy was a snap:
http://tinyurl.com/crrw3gz

Yes, really..... the Dixie Chicks, whose lead singer said in 2003....

"we don't want this war, this violence, and we're ashamed that the President of the United States [George W. Bush] is from Texas".

...The Dixie Chicks - the all-time top selling all-female band, and biggest selling country group in the U.S. during the Nielsen SoundScan era. A group whose great songs are still banned by most country stations.

How exactly has the White House made Woodward sound like a kook? Could it be that Woodward indeed sounded like that? Professor Krugman seemed to agree: http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/28/gene-sperling-doesnt-respect...

Others did too: http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/johncassidy/2013/02/bob-woodward-t...

Did you ever think Bob Woodward was a respected journalist? Check out the respected clause there. Katie Couric perhaps but you believe he was a hero in Watergate? What was his partners name? If you get further into the truth he forced Woodward into staying true to the cause in divulging the truth.

Your article was pretty good until you mentioned the Dixie Chicks. Geesh...the Dixie Chicks, really?

And what about Bob Woodward? The White House wasn't too happy with him and took a respected journalist and made him sound like a kook. And we have not heard much since. No wonder we cannot get honest reporting anymore. Everyone seems afraid in this world of social media where one comment or slice of an out of context video can go viral in an instant whether factual or not. Scary when you think about it.

Where is Walter Cronkite when you need him? Who is "the most trusted man in America" now?

I dont really think so. I went to India, Delhi specifically, one month after the tragic rape of the 22 year old medical student which caused many riots and upheaval. Every plane I took was packed with tourists, every hotel was sold out (mostly with Americans) and in talking with the hotels they said they had not recieved one cancellation. The westerners in the hotels said they didnt even think about cancelling their trips and said they felt "safe" in and about India. Friends and colleagues who have plans to travel this summer have not changed them. I doubt many people have cancelled their trips to the US because of Sandy Hook or Columbine- the same will be true for India, right or wrong.

Remember the day when the physician in reading the ekg, began to take action on the findings he/she was evaluating. Only when the nurse reminded he/she that the ekg he/she was reading was being read upside down did he/she relent in taking action.

Walter Cronkite passed away. We still have Dan Rather, however. He was silenced by the Bushies when he dared open his mouth. He does appear regularly on Rachel Maddow and he's still as sharp as ever. His language is still peppered with funny Texas colloquialism.

What if the story turned out the other way around and the patient was having an MI? I've witnessed plenty of episodes where arrogant MDs dismissed nurses concerns only to be proven wrong. Rare is the apology or admission of fault from MD to RN. A quick cardiology consult would certainly not put this patient at risk or significantly delay therapy, but ignoring an MI and proceeding with transplant would almost surely kill him. Being nice to colleagues in health care gets you further than confrontation.

I made the "mistake" in training of reporting a nurse who did not follow clinical protocols and did not notify the intern in a timely manner about a very ill child, despite her assessment being that the child was very ill, thereby endangering the child's life. The child survived because the intern happened to poke her head in the door on walk rounds. My life was made hell after that, with anonymous complaints made, many of which were completely fabricated. Many were very personal and petty addressing my appearance (I am a woman) and it was just like being 13 again, except being a professional in my late 20s. I am sure it was a tiny minority of nurses involved, but no one ever in my group of residents ever dared use the reporting system again.....

Your comments demonstrate the point of the article.....
too bad for the professionals who work in your hospital that you have so little self awareness.

Most of the nurses I work with are excellent - I would trust my own family members to their care without a second thought.  But nurses like Ms. Brown,  with chips on their shoulder, axes to grind and little education are a danger to patients.  Incorrectly interpreting an EKG, challenging the physician who correctly interpreted it, and trying to put a life-saving transplant on hold is a threat to patient safety and care.   Quite frankly, one can only hope the doctor in question reported her. Doctors are typically too busy to report or write up a bad nurse - the problem with this is that bad nurses like Brown can hang on for years.

It's not just metric. For some measures, SI units substitute moles (or millimoles or micromoles) for liters (or deciliters). So, for clinical laboratory results in medical practice....currently metric....SI units mean another conversion. It ain't pretty.

Well said. India certainly does not deserve a Nobel-prize for its treatment of women, but neither does the US. I am a doctor (gynecologist) and can tell you the number of women who have been subjected to sexual harrassment, assualt and trauma still astounds me to this day. We live in country where 1 in 4 college age women reports sexual assualt/harrassment, where women still make only 77 cents to the dollar that a man makes and still have failed to elect women to the highest offices in the land. I worked at the VA hospital and nearly 90% of women in our armed forces have been assaulted or  harrassed by their male counterparts. Absolutely nothing was done to address their issues other than retribution. Only 20% of women report sexual assault so the incidence of rape in the US is FAR higher than what our national statistics report. Its easy to demonize a third world country 8000 miles away when we still have a pervasive culture of "boys will be boys" right here at home.
